dataset_information.population_sample: nationally representative sample of women and households
dataset_information.data_cleaning: Wealth scores were generated separately for each area to account for differences in scales. First- and second-order temporal dummy variables were included in the regression to address duration dependence of the hazard function.

usage_in_paper.specifics: Used to examine the relationship between household wealth and child health outcomes such as mortality and malnutrition

study_context.study_title: Household wealth and child health in India

dependent_variables.name: Infant mortality, Child mortality, Under-5 mortality, Stunting, Wasting, Underweight

independent_variables.name: Household wealth
categories: Lowest, Second, Middle, Fourth, Highest wealth quintiles

independent_variables.name: Mother's education, Birth order, Birth interval, Improved drinking water, Improved sanitation facility, Solid cooking fuel, Urban household, Father's education, Religion
categories: Education levels, Household characteristics, Socioeconomic factors
